I find in model.fit, 

If I set kvstore = local_allreduce_device. It will not converge.
If I set kvstore = local_allreduce_cpu or local_update_cpu. It will converge.

So, why local_allreduce_device failed?

In doc, it says:
- `local_allreduce_device` 类似于 `local_allreduce_cpu` 除了梯度平均计算是在一个选定的设备上进行的. 这种模式可以利用设备到设备之间的点对点传输的特性, 可能加速平均计算的速度. 如果梯度很大的话, 它会比 `local_allreduce_cpu`  模式快, 但是利用更多的设备内存.

@piiswrong I look into the code and I find that after `PooledStorageManager::ReleaseAll()` `used_memory_` equals 0. However, `nvidia-smi` still reports memory occupied. I'm confused and not sure which is correct.
for the new verision of mxnet, make_list.py is deleted, you can get it from the old version, for instance 20160202.
You can try " label = mx.sym.Variable('softmax_label', shape=(100, 16)) ". And I think before you reshape the label you should transpose it.
You can refer to the code in `im2rec.py`, it supports multi-label regression. Indeed, it uses  `float(x)` to convert x from string to float-number(even x is a label).

I think it is related to cudnn version.
I tested cudnn4+cuda8 in ubuntu 16.04 with gtx1080. I got very bad accuracy.
But I get very good accuracy when change to cudnn5

to get .lst file
python make_list.py images/   images/train  --recursive=True
then you can get train.lst in file folder images/
to get .rec file
python im2rec.py images/train   images/train
then you can get train.rec in file folder images/
@Godricly Hi, do you have some examples of using fp16? Is it used in training or inference?

Not yet. Basically, u can insert some cast layer to transform input(data and label) into fp16, so the network flows in fp16. Currently, mxnet has compatible issue with fp16, so I cancelled my previous PR #2564.

 If you are interested in fp16, u can follow my [branch](https://github.com/Godricly/mxnet/tree/DTypeSupport) to enable fp16 param init and single machine training, the multi machine one depends ps-lite which is a little bit hard to get it work. 

U also need to make some modification on optimizer, which use float type to update weights and convert them back to fp16 in network.  

For the lstm case, the provided data type is need, which is painful. If you have any better solution, please let me know. 😆 

BTW, the DType BN is only functional using cudnn.
could you update to master?

data=[data0, data1, data2] is equivalent to *[data0, data1, data2].
Also please change the names. MXNet convention is usually num_xxx instead of xxx_num.

Other than that its good.
Thanks a lot

PS. also please rebase to master
your cuda is installed in /opt/cuda instead of /usr/local/cuda. So you need to modify CUDA_PATH in config.mk
please update to current master and recompile
you need to `cp make/osx.mk config.mk` then modify the config.mk in root folder
look into examples/rnn

update: GPU memory is only recycled when my `main` function is over and this is not surprising. However, the automatically called `GPUDeviceStorage::Free()` due to the deconstrction of `PooledStorageManager` at the end of the `main` function reports `cudaErrorCudartUnloading` and thus the allocated GPU memory is not released. 
Just for a test, I manually delete the storage manager before the `main` function ends. The allocated memory is freed as expected. So I'm wondering is it a potential bug in `PooledStorageManager` in releasing GPU memory? @piiswrong @tqchen
That makes sense. Thanks!
Sure I just rebased to master.

@yechaochen  You can try it.  

In `im2rec.py`: 

```
def read_list(path_in):
    image_list = []
    with open(path_in) as fin:
        for line in fin.readlines():
            line = [i.strip() for i in line.strip().split('\t')]
            item = [int(line[0])] + [line[-1]] + [float(i) for i in line[1:-1]]
            image_list.append(item)
    return image_list
```

This is how it reads the .lst file.

@Godricly Division should be non-differentiable when the denominator is zero.
What about using the 3x3/2 pooling with pad=1? Pre-trained models may still degrade in accuracy though. There seems an offset of one pixel between this implementation and the previous.
In my case, the value are small before square takes action. I think the square is returning sth with zero, which leads NaN in my case.

http://mxnet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/packages/python/io.html
Details can be referred to in this web.
@Godricly I see. We can add another eps value to the denominator when calling `broadcast_div`. Like `c = mx.sym.broadcast_div(a, b + 1E-6)`

@yechaochen  I think even your labels are integers, they will also be converted to float-type numbers.  You'd better try it, and to see whether or not.

**## Extension: Mutliple Labels for a Single Image**

> The im2rec tool and mx.io.ImageRecordIter also has a mutli-label support for a single image. Assume you have 4 labels for a single image, you can take the following steps to utilize the RecordIO tools.
> Write the the image list files as follows:

`integer_image_index \t label_1 \t label_2 \t label_3 \t label_4 \t path_to_image`

> When use im2rec tools, add a ‘label_width=4’ to the command argument, e.g.

`./bin/im2rec image.lst image_root_dir output.bin resize=256 label_width=4`

> In your iterator generation code, set label_width=4 and path_imglist=<<The PATH TO YOUR image.lst>>, e.g.

```
dataiter = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
  path_imgrec="data/cifar/train.rec",
  data_shape=(3,28,28),
  path_imglist="data/cifar/image.lst",
  label_width=4
)
```

> Then you’re all set for a multi-label image iterator.

This works for me.

@tqchen @thirdwing @pluskid @sneakerkg Hi, I am trying to create the model using FeedForward using mxnet_predict-all.cc, instead of using it as predictor, as I want to run this process on mobile device instead of a desktop/server. 

What I need to know is how do I pass the values of `const void* param_bytes`, in the function mentioned below. On my local I can do this by passing a dictionary (python) with key as names of the layers and values as NDArray 4D arrays. 

How do I achieve the same result by using the fucntion below 
- \brief create a predictor
  - \param symbol_json_str The JSON string of the symbol.
  - \param param_bytes The in-memory raw bytes of parameter ndarray file.
  - \param param_size The size of parameter ndarray file.
  - \param dev_type The device type, 1: cpu, 2:gpu
  - \param dev_id The device id of the predictor.
  - \param num_input_nodes Number of input nodes to the net,
  -    For feedforward net, this is 1.
  - \param input_keys The name of input argument.
  -    For feedforward net, this is {"data"}
  - \param input_shape_indptr Index pointer of shapes of each input node.
  -    The length of this array = num_input_nodes + 1.
  -    For feedforward net that takes 4 dimensional input, this is {0, 4}.
  - \param input_shape_data A flatted data of shapes of each input node.
  -    For feedforward net that takes 4 dimensional input, this is the shape data.
  - \param out The created predictor handle.
  - \return 0 when success, -1 when failure.
    */

```
MXNET_DLL int MXPredCreate(const char* symbol_json_str,
                           const void* param_bytes,
                           int param_size,
                           int dev_type, int dev_id,
                           mx_uint num_input_nodes,
                           const char** input_keys,
                           const mx_uint* input_shape_indptr,
                           const mx_uint* input_shape_data,
                           PredictorHandle* out);
```

please update to current master

@csucat Well, I don't think it has anything to do with your compilation since `make` reports no error.  As @Ldpe2G suggests, it is strange that python requires the 7.0 version of the lib instead of 7.5. You can check that first.

@csucat At a second thought, if you are using the latest Mxnet, the python version should not be version 0.5. Maybe 0.7 or higher, I'm not quite sure. I think you previously installed a older version of mxnet python wrapper and at that time cuda 7.0 was installed on your system. So I suggest you to reinstall your python wrapper again so your `site-packages` can be updated.

@wshenx yeah, I have installed mxnet when the server was using the cuda7.0 drivers, and then the cuda 7.5 driver was installed and the cuda 7.0 driver was removed.  I deleted the mxnet root directory and download the mxnet project again according to the install instructions(`git clone --recursive https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet`). By the way, originally, I use the system-provided python when I was compiling the mxnet package, but now I am using Anaconda.

@piiswrong @tqchen Do you think we should have an interface to clear GPU memory since there are situations users want to release all the memory allocated (#1946,#1677, #1432, #1301). Though it might be contrary to the memory usage scheme of mxnet engine, a force clear of all the memory is sometimes worthwhile.
yeah, a fresh new installation usually helps~

@wshenx, Problem Solved!!  I thought the system-provided python and anaconda have nothing to with each other.  Apparently I was wrong. The output of `conda list | grep mxnet` only shows that mxnet version 0.7 was installed. But when I use `pip uninstall mxnet`(this pip is from anaconda), surprisingly,  mxnet version 0.5 was uninstalled. Using the command again uninstalled the mxnet version 0.7.  Finally, reinstalling mxnet python wrapper solved the problem.
For anyone who has met this problem: make sure that any previous install of mxnet wrapper is removed and then reinstall the new mxnet wrapper.

Fixed the lint and complement the patch in caffe docs.
